Here’s why</div></h1></div><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-10 mck-u-animation-blur-in-800 ArticleDefault_mck-c-article-default__description__sjoe9"><div><time datetime="2022-11-04T00:00:00Z">November 4, 2022</time> | Article</div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="mck-o-container"><div class="mck-o-container--wrapped mck-o-container--mobile-spacing mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><section data-layer-region="article-body-header" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400 byline-share-container"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-8 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-8 mdc-u-ts-9"><span>By </span><span>Claudy Jules</span><span> and </span><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/our-people/jason-phillips" class="mdc-c-link-inline___7DRrt_990311c mdc-c-link-inline--secondary___YKoOK_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Jason Phillips</span></a></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11 ArticleContent_mck-c-article-content__share-tools__kWRRw"></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">Operating groups gain an edge when they add a CPO, but these roles are still rare in private equity firms. That should change.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fprivate%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors%2Four%20insights%2Fchief%20performance%20officers%20can%20be%20a%20secret%20ingredient%20for%20private%20equity%20success%20heres%20why%2Fchief-performance-officers-can-be-a-secret-ingredient-for-private-equity-success-heres-why.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="chief-performance-officers-can-be-a-secret-ingredient-for-private-equity-success-heres-why" data-layer-report-name="chief-performance-officers-can-be-a-secret-ingredient-for-private-equity-success-heres-why>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (7 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Most leaders, </strong>and by extension, most companies, talk about people being their greatest asset. In the fast-moving world of private investments, executive talent is even more crucial. Due diligence decisions in private equity (PE) can often hinge on talent issues. Growth equity, likewise, is grounded in questions of human capital, as investors work to turn good companies into great companies. The success of venture capital investments can be even more reliant on the quality of the existing leadership team. Across the sector, private investment firms conduct ongoing audits of top executives’ performance and may take swift action when it falters, consistent with their fiduciary obligation to their investors.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>“You won’t be successful unless you have the right people, the right dynamics, and the right culture,” advised one PE firm partner who focuses on early- and growth-stage companies. Said another PE leader: “It is almost certain that the executive leadership team that took the company from zero to $50 million is not the same team to scale to $300 million or $500 million.”</p>
<p>For all of PE’s preoccupation with talent, it’s still somewhat unusual for firms to have a chief performance officer (CPO), who is sometimes called the “human capital operating partner” or “portfolio talent lead.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e83c386b-e3f1-4b5d-b671-c178c940f5ff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e83c386b-e3f1-4b5d-b671-c178c940f5ff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Throughout the article, we label this role “CPO,” though the other titles are synonymous and equally valid.</span></span></span></a></span> In our latest survey of PE operating groups, half of firms with more than $2 billion in assets under management (AUM) had at least one talent specialist—either mid- or senior-level. These experts are rare in firms with less than $2 billion in AUM: only two out of 13 firms surveyed reported having such an executive. Talent-oriented partners often focus on working their contact lists and relationships with search firms to identify and place talent in jobs. However, some components of the talent picture may still be missing: even talent-focused operating partners may lack the specific skills to <a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/winning-at-private-equity-integrations">support portfolio companies through acquisitions and integrations</a>. Senior executives may incorrectly use hierarchy, relationships, or intuition to determine how talent affects value creation.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Another role to consider: The chief diversity, equity, and inclusion officer</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Private equity,</strong> through its ownership and practices, can have an outsize influence on portfolio companies’ diversity. PE firms often reshape top management, boards, as well as the policies and practices inside these companies. Even if the holding period is just three years, changes can endure. Considering that PE firms directly or indirectly employ millions of workers globally, the opportunity to open doors for diverse demographics, <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters">strengthen companies through diversity</a>, and positively affect society can be significant.</p>
<p>PE firms ambitious about making lasting changes might consider <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/making-the-world-a-better-place-never-feels-like-work-an-interview-with-chief-dei-officer-indhira-arrington">hiring a chief diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) officer</a>. These executives can add value in three main ways.</p>
<ol>
    <li>The officer can advise on DEI, building a measurable, holistic strategy and helping with cultural matters related to the topic. This includes troubleshooting portfolio company issues and helping recruit a diverse board.</li>
    <li>The executive can lead DEI for the PE firm itself. This could include running diagnostics to identify high-priority DEI issues, developing transformation road maps, analyzing industry-specific talent pools to inform action plans, building DEI capabilities across the PE firm, and implementing mentorship or sponsorship programs or employee resource groups.</li>
    <li>The officer can increase the pool of underrepresented talent considered for key roles. In most private investment firms with a human capital team, the goal for the DEI partner is not necessarily to source talent (which is typically part of the CPO’s executive search function). However, if there is interest in finding a diverse board member, there is a good chance that an investor will tap the DEI partner to assist. In cases where there is explicit interest in hiring a CHRO for a portfolio company, a chief DEI officer may get involved.</li>
</ol>
<p>In addition to supporting board searches, heads of DEI may also increase the pipeline of underrepresented founders that investors are aware of and with whom they speak and meet. The goal is to ultimately deploy more capital to these entrepreneurs.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The relative lack of CPOs may represent a lost opportunity for PE. A great CPO contributes to diligence and the creation of an investment thesis in critical ways. They assess whether C-suite leaders have the capabilities to deliver on the deal thesis, as well as whether the workforce has the scale or depth of skill required. They identify cultural issues that could provoke problems, such as a talent exodus or work slowdown, and flag inefficiencies throughout the organizational structure. CPOs are experts in organizational change, deploying people analytics that make understanding talent as data-driven as any other business metric, and creating collaborative networks of chief human resources officers (CHROs) across a firm’s portfolio companies.</p>
<p>CPOs are also instrumental in expanding diverse talent within portfolio companies (see sidebar, “Another role to consider: The chief diversity, equity, and inclusion officer”).</p>
<p>For firms that don’t have a CPO on board, there are three main aspects to consider:</p>
<ul>
    <li>the value CPOs bring to each phase of a PE deal cycle</li>
    <li>the skills the CPO role requires</li>
    <li>how to hire a CPO</li>
</ul>
<p>Creating and filling a CPO role isn’t easy, for reasons captured in one CPO’s observation: “Being a good CPO requires you make the CEO happy, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/climbing-the-private-equity-learning-curve">keep the deal partner informed</a>, and be an expert, all while engaging your sense of diplomacy rather than offering critiques.” But the reward—gaining a talent edge in an industry where human capital makes a crucial difference—makes adding a CPO to the operating group a goal worth pursuing.</p>
<h2>The value CPOs bring to each phase of a PE deal cycle</h2>
<p>Arguably, a CPO’s most crucial contributions can be made immediately post-announcement, when they work on an integrated value creation agenda for the new portfolio company. From then on, they will be judged by how they leverage their expertise, build an ecosystem, craft incentives and compensation plans that reward attractive returns, and overcome organizational inertia. The job essentially consists of five distinct roles, each with its own demands.</p>
<h3>The CPO as due diligence adviser</h3>
<p>Before acquisition, the CPO functions primarily as a due diligence adviser who analyzes a target company through the lens of its existing talent and organizational health (exhibit). For some CPOs, most of their work in this phase is to ensure a strong management team is in place before their firm invests.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/chief%20performance%20officers%20can%20be%20a%20secret%20ingredient%20for%20private%20equity%20success%20heres%20why/svgz-cpodashboard-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="CPOs can provide organizational health assessments that inform investment decisions, synergies, and improvements (illustrative). " src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/private%20equity%20and%20principal%20investors/our%20insights/chief%20performance%20officers%20can%20be%20a%20secret%20ingredient%20for%20private%20equity%20success%20heres%20why/svgz-cpodashboard-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>“It’s hard for my partners to want to make an investment if there isn’t a strong management team in the beginning,” said a partner and chief talent officer of a PE firm that makes investments through leveraged buyouts and as growth capital investments. “If I have to [completely change] a management team, then that means I didn’t do my work during due diligence.”</p>
<p>From day one of deal selection, the CPO is the go-to person for answers to talent questions that relate to what it will take to execute against the value creation plan. After a deal closes, CPOs often work with deal teams and senior management to create an organizational strategy as part of an integrated value creation agenda for the new portfolio company to ensure delivery of the investment thesis.</p>
<h3>The CPO as the post-close CEO whisperer</h3>
<p>CPOs work with portfolio management teams to execute organization effectiveness initiatives from day one and then to monitor progress against plans. This requires that they immediately develop strong partnerships with CEOs and senior leadership teams within portfolio companies. It can also mean coaching and counseling leaders (<a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/a-playbook-for-newly-minted-private-equity-portfolio-company-ceos">especially newly minted private equity portfolio CEOs</a>) and other senior executives on organizational matters or convening them at roundtables so they can learn from one another.</p>
<h3>The CPO as a talent shaper</h3>
<p>Early in the deal cycle, the CPO becomes a talent shaper who develops scorecards for how well senior leaders deliver on goals. These can be used for performance evaluation, hiring, or off-boarding decisions at the portfolio companies.</p>
<p>CPOs often play a role in placing leadership talent, which is one of the reasons why they are sometimes sourced from executive search firms. They cultivate and manage executive talent pipelines for typical roles across the portfolio, including CEO, COO, CFO—and chief product officer and revenue officer for software companies—in partnership with other operating leaders in these functional areas.</p>
<h3>The CPO as transformation architect</h3>
<p>CPOs must provide sound strategic guidance based on the right data and incentives and by leveraging analytics while pushing forward performance improvement and change initiatives. They can transform companies by increasing organizational alignment and health while bolstering not just the caliber of the portfolio companies’ boards and management teams but all the roles that support value creation.</p>
<p>A CPO explained, “We look at whether the portfolio company has demonstrated evidence of doing change well. Then we look ahead at the three-to-five-year time frame, at what organizational capabilities the company is competitively capable of winning in a compressed time frame. Have they done it, can they do it, and what will be required?” Whether it’s to steer organizational and operational initiatives for margin expansion or growth, CPOs must show that they have the courage to lead change management efforts if necessary.</p>
<h3>A leader for portfolio companies’ CHROs</h3>
<p>A CPO can add value by serving as a leader for and conduit between a PE firm’s various portfolio company CHROs. The importance of this coordination became apparent to <a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/how-private-equity-operating-groups-are-taking-on-the-challenge-of-the-coronavirus">PE firms at the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic</a>, when they quickly established health and safety protocols and remote work across their portfolios. As those needs have receded, firms have maintained networks of portfolio CHROs to address current issues including developing talent, creating flexible work systems, and building company culture.</p>
<p>CPOs can lead these networks. They might oversee roundtables, access to external experts, collation and distribution of relevant reports, articles, and materials, and other ways for CHROs to share and learn. This comradery is especially valuable because of the solitary nature of the CHRO role, which can leave some executives feeling isolated.</p>
<p>“Having a trusted thought partner to bounce ideas off, to get another perspective, and ensure you are headed in the right direction can be very valuable,” said a CHRO about having a CPO mentor.</p>
<p>CPOs also can leverage purchasing power for their portfolio companies, negotiating the best deals with providers of technology and other programs at reasonable prices. Smaller companies can enjoy the purchasing power of a larger enterprise by virtue of this collaboration.</p>
<h2>The skills the CPO role requires</h2>
<p>When asked to explain his job, a CPO made it sound simple: “My role is getting the right leader into the right role and then getting the team behind that leader.” Drilling down into that description, however, reveals a bedrock of expertise. Knowing who is the right leader, what is the right role, and how to get a team in place that will provide optimal support requires a unique package of mindset, experience, and ability.</p>
<h3>The investor mindset</h3>
<p>First and perhaps foremost, the commercial nature of the role means a CPO must possess an investor mindset. They should operate as unsentimental owners focused on business performance and investor returns across multiple portfolio companies. They should have a “nose for value”—that is, a strong sense of how a portfolio company can both grow and marshal resources. To be effective in her role, a CPO said she has to ask herself, “Would you put your own money in this company and back this?”</p>
<h3>Diplomatic prowess</h3>
<p>Because they need to act as pragmatic advisers to both deal teams and senior portfolio management teams, CPOs must engage in a web of complicated relationships. They have to be able to serve as strategic advisers, leadership coaches, key business-decision influencers, thought partners, and cooperative skeptics for multiple CEOs, management teams, and the investment team.</p>
<h3>A metabolic rate geared to PE</h3>
<p>CPOs must deal effectively with the high stakes and urgency required by working with a PE portfolio company. They must be able to roll up their sleeves, think and act quickly, prioritize, and be decisive. Operating successfully requires a hands-on consultative approach with a bias toward coaching and action.</p>
<p>Describing the pace of her job, one CPO said, “Everything we do at our firm in the talent and organization space is about speed to impact. It’s about fast insight, disciplined process, and data gathering.” Any initiative the CPO takes has to prioritize the business and its goals rather than a rigid set of standard practices. CPOs need to possess a real talent for creative, flexible thinking, so that they can contribute without adding burdensome layers to processes and systems.</p>
<h3>Exceptional interpersonal skills</h3>
<p>CPOs need to act as confidantes, which often involves managing many leaders’ private communication responsibly. Therefore, they must be highly strategic leaders themselves, who build credibility by modeling gravitas. They should be prepared to take unpopular stands while demonstrating low ego, strong communication skills, and flexibility. Most of all, they should always offer solutions. This is especially important for identifying and recommending performance improvements to critical strategic, operational, and organizational areas. It takes an enterprise mindset to determine the right resources, processes, and data to gather and communicate.</p>
<h3>High emotional intelligence</h3>
<p>To advise competently, CPOs must be able to read complex human and organizational dynamics. This can be tricky in high stakes situations in which pressure and complexities compound. CPOs need to know when to raise red flags and when to deliver tough messages—such as saying what the investor or portfolio CEO needs to hear, rather than what they might want to hear.</p>
<h2>How to hire a CPO</h2>
<p>It can be a tall order to find some someone with a track record of driving transformation who also has the business acumen to advise C-suite leaders and investment professionals across a multisectoral portfolio.</p>
<p>PE firms often find CPOs from three types of backgrounds or combinations thereof: qualified candidates tend to be organizational psychologists who do assessment and coaching work; former HR or executive search professionals; or people with relevant experience in private companies, including in other roles in PE firms.</p>
<p>Whatever the CPO’s original background, it’s important to remember that the role changes based on the phase of the deal cycle and that the candidates must be able to perform in all phases. Every CPO will need to be armed with intelligent digital systems to help identify the critical improvements needed for at-risk roles and the organization’s health. Lastly, a potential CPO should have firsthand, practical experience in propelling change—academic or theoretical knowledge isn’t enough.</p>
<h3>CPOs with backgrounds in organizational psychology</h3>
<p>These candidates often possess deep knowledge of organizational design and effectiveness, including the use of assessments to understand the health of an organization. This background can be helpful when CPOs must look at an underperforming business through the lens of organizational drivers. These candidates are particularly suited to understanding the culture and capabilities that are lacking, analyzing C-suite dynamics, and aligning the company’s organizational health to the investment thesis and value creation plan.</p>
<h3>CPOs coming from HR or executive search</h3>
<p>A CPO with a strong executive search background and digital rolodex of high-caliber talent can be a huge value-add. Similarly, someone who has been a talent leader and operator inside a company can bring a broad perspective regarding pitfalls to avoid and ways to deliver results.</p>
<h3>CPOs with relevant private industry experience</h3>
<p>Some candidates come from management consulting or PE firms that have truly invested in this capability. People with these backgrounds can offer a track record of working with CEOs to improve organizational performance, an analytical “investor mindset,” emotional intelligence, exceptional interpersonal and communication skills, and the ability to operate fast.</p>
<hr>
<p>Historically, investment teams haven’t systematically thought about talent and organization in a structured way, leading to blind spots—especially after diligence. PE firms and their limited partners can no longer assume intangible assets such as human capital and culture—which have been estimated to comprise an average of 52 percent of a company’s market value<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9e3959f5-9d2e-4b76-ac69-c7d8e14db989"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9e3959f5-9d2e-4b76-ac69-c7d8e14db989" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global Intangible Finance Tracker (GIFT) 2018</em>, Brand Finance, October 2018.</span></span></span></a></span>—will take care of themselves. Bringing in a top-tier CPO gives investment firms and their portfolio companies an edge over firms whose portfolio optimization groups haven’t yet evolved to include such a role.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-xs-12 mck-c-enhanced-author"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-xs-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-xs-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h2><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-xs-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-2 mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-mt-5"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-xs-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-xs-span-4"><div data-component="mdc-c-avatar" class="mdc-c-avatar-enhanced-author-0 mdc-c-avatar___kVSTP_990311c mdc-c-avatar--image-placeholder___BX3C4_990311c mdc-c-avatar--size-4"><style>

aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Chief performance officers can be a secret ingredient for private equity success Heres why","displayName":"Chief performance officers can be a secret ingredient for private equity success Heres why","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"841a7104-92f4-4d36-bafe-155d6bdb2378","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Chief performance officers can be a secret ingredient for private equity success. Here\u0026rsquo;s why"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Chief performance officers in private equity firms"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Operating groups gain an edge when they add a CPO, but these roles are still rare in private equity firms. That should change."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Operating groups gain an edge when they add a chief performance officer (CPO), but these roles are still rare in private equity firms. That should change."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-11-04T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMost leaders, \u003c/strong\u003eand by extension, most companies, talk about people being their greatest asset. In the fast-moving world of private investments, executive talent is even more crucial. Due diligence decisions in private equity (PE) can often hinge on talent issues. Growth equity, likewise, is grounded in questions of human capital, as investors work to turn good companies into great companies. The success of venture capital investments can be even more reliant on the quality of the existing leadership team. Across the sector, private investment firms conduct ongoing audits of top executives\u0026rsquo; performance and may take swift action when it falters, consistent with their fiduciary obligation to their investors.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;You won\u0026rsquo;t be successful unless you have the right people, the right dynamics, and the right culture,\u0026rdquo; advised one PE firm partner who focuses on early- and growth-stage companies. Said another PE leader: \u0026ldquo;It is almost certain that the executive leadership team that took the company from zero to $50 million is not the same team to scale to $300 million or $500 million.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor all of PE\u0026rsquo;s preoccupation with talent, it\u0026rsquo;s still somewhat unusual for firms to have a chief performance officer (CPO), who is sometimes called the \u0026ldquo;human capital operating partner\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;portfolio talent lead.\u0026rdquo;[[footnote 1]] In our latest survey of PE operating groups, half of firms with more than $2 billion in assets under management (AUM) had at least one talent specialist\u0026mdash;either mid- or senior-level. These experts are rare in firms with less than $2 billion in AUM: only two out of 13 firms surveyed reported having such an executive. Talent-oriented partners often focus on working their contact lists and relationships with search firms to identify and place talent in jobs. However, some components of the talent picture may still be missing: even talent-focused operating partners may lack the specific skills to \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/winning-at-private-equity-integrations\"\u003esupport portfolio companies through acquisitions and integrations\u003c/a\u003e. Senior executives may incorrectly use hierarchy, relationships, or intuition to determine how talent affects value creation.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe relative lack of CPOs may represent a lost opportunity for PE. A great CPO contributes to diligence and the creation of an investment thesis in critical ways. They assess whether C-suite leaders have the capabilities to deliver on the deal thesis, as well as whether the workforce has the scale or depth of skill required. They identify cultural issues that could provoke problems, such as a talent exodus or work slowdown, and flag inefficiencies throughout the organizational structure. CPOs are experts in organizational change, deploying people analytics that make understanding talent as data-driven as any other business metric, and creating collaborative networks of chief human resources officers (CHROs) across a firm\u0026rsquo;s portfolio companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs are also instrumental in expanding diverse talent within portfolio companies (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Another role to consider: The chief diversity, equity, and inclusion officer\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor firms that don\u0026rsquo;t have a CPO on board, there are three main aspects to consider:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ethe value CPOs bring to each phase of a PE deal cycle\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ethe skills the CPO role requires\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003ehow to hire a CPO\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCreating and filling a CPO role isn\u0026rsquo;t easy, for reasons captured in one CPO\u0026rsquo;s observation: \u0026ldquo;Being a good CPO requires you make the CEO happy, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/climbing-the-private-equity-learning-curve\"\u003ekeep the deal partner informed\u003c/a\u003e, and be an expert, all while engaging your sense of diplomacy rather than offering critiques.\u0026rdquo; But the reward\u0026mdash;gaining a talent edge in an industry where human capital makes a crucial difference\u0026mdash;makes adding a CPO to the operating group a goal worth pursuing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe value CPOs bring to each phase of a PE deal cycle\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eArguably, a CPO\u0026rsquo;s most crucial contributions can be made immediately post-announcement, when they work on an integrated value creation agenda for the new portfolio company. From then on, they will be judged by how they leverage their expertise, build an ecosystem, craft incentives and compensation plans that reward attractive returns, and overcome organizational inertia. The job essentially consists of five distinct roles, each with its own demands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe CPO as due diligence adviser\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBefore acquisition, the CPO functions primarily as a due diligence adviser who analyzes a target company through the lens of its existing talent and organizational health (exhibit). For some CPOs, most of their work in this phase is to ensure a strong management team is in place before their firm invests.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;It\u0026rsquo;s hard for my partners to want to make an investment if there isn\u0026rsquo;t a strong management team in the beginning,\u0026rdquo; said a partner and chief talent officer of a PE firm that makes investments through leveraged buyouts and as growth capital investments. \u0026ldquo;If I have to [completely change] a management team, then that means I didn\u0026rsquo;t do my work during due diligence.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrom day one of deal selection, the CPO is the go-to person for answers to talent questions that relate to what it will take to execute against the value creation plan. After a deal closes, CPOs often work with deal teams and senior management to create an organizational strategy as part of an integrated value creation agenda for the new portfolio company to ensure delivery of the investment thesis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe CPO as the post-close CEO whisperer\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs work with portfolio management teams to execute organization effectiveness initiatives from day one and then to monitor progress against plans. This requires that they immediately develop strong partnerships with CEOs and senior leadership teams within portfolio companies. It can also mean coaching and counseling leaders (\u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/a-playbook-for-newly-minted-private-equity-portfolio-company-ceos\"\u003eespecially newly minted private equity portfolio CEOs\u003c/a\u003e) and other senior executives on organizational matters or convening them at roundtables so they can learn from one another.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe CPO as a talent shaper\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarly in the deal cycle, the CPO becomes a talent shaper who develops scorecards for how well senior leaders deliver on goals. These can be used for performance evaluation, hiring, or off-boarding decisions at the portfolio companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs often play a role in placing leadership talent, which is one of the reasons why they are sometimes sourced from executive search firms. They cultivate and manage executive talent pipelines for typical roles across the portfolio, including CEO, COO, CFO\u0026mdash;and chief product officer and revenue officer for software companies\u0026mdash;in partnership with other operating leaders in these functional areas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe CPO as transformation architect\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs must provide sound strategic guidance based on the right data and incentives and by leveraging analytics while pushing forward performance improvement and change initiatives. They can transform companies by increasing organizational alignment and health while bolstering not just the caliber of the portfolio companies\u0026rsquo; boards and management teams but all the roles that support value creation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA CPO explained, \u0026ldquo;We look at whether the portfolio company has demonstrated evidence of doing change well. Then we look ahead at the three-to-five-year time frame, at what organizational capabilities the company is competitively capable of winning in a compressed time frame. Have they done it, can they do it, and what will be required?\u0026rdquo; Whether it\u0026rsquo;s to steer organizational and operational initiatives for margin expansion or growth, CPOs must show that they have the courage to lead change management efforts if necessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA leader for portfolio companies\u0026rsquo; CHROs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA CPO can add value by serving as a leader for and conduit between a PE firm\u0026rsquo;s various portfolio company CHROs. The importance of this coordination became apparent to \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/how-private-equity-operating-groups-are-taking-on-the-challenge-of-the-coronavirus\"\u003ePE firms at the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic\u003c/a\u003e, when they quickly established health and safety protocols and remote work across their portfolios. As those needs have receded, firms have maintained networks of portfolio CHROs to address current issues including developing talent, creating flexible work systems, and building company culture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs can lead these networks. They might oversee roundtables, access to external experts, collation and distribution of relevant reports, articles, and materials, and other ways for CHROs to share and learn. This comradery is especially valuable because of the solitary nature of the CHRO role, which can leave some executives feeling isolated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026ldquo;Having a trusted thought partner to bounce ideas off, to get another perspective, and ensure you are headed in the right direction can be very valuable,\u0026rdquo; said a CHRO about having a CPO mentor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs also can leverage purchasing power for their portfolio companies, negotiating the best deals with providers of technology and other programs at reasonable prices. Smaller companies can enjoy the purchasing power of a larger enterprise by virtue of this collaboration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe skills the CPO role requires\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhen asked to explain his job, a CPO made it sound simple: \u0026ldquo;My role is getting the right leader into the right role and then getting the team behind that leader.\u0026rdquo; Drilling down into that description, however, reveals a bedrock of expertise. Knowing who is the right leader, what is the right role, and how to get a team in place that will provide optimal support requires a unique package of mindset, experience, and ability.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe investor mindset\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst and perhaps foremost, the commercial nature of the role means a CPO must possess an investor mindset. They should operate as unsentimental owners focused on business performance and investor returns across multiple portfolio companies. They should have a \u0026ldquo;nose for value\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;that is, a strong sense of how a portfolio company can both grow and marshal resources. To be effective in her role, a CPO said she has to ask herself, \u0026ldquo;Would you put your own money in this company and back this?\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDiplomatic prowess\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause they need to act as pragmatic advisers to both deal teams and senior portfolio management teams, CPOs must engage in a web of complicated relationships. They have to be able to serve as strategic advisers, leadership coaches, key business-decision influencers, thought partners, and cooperative skeptics for multiple CEOs, management teams, and the investment team.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eA metabolic rate geared to PE\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs must deal effectively with the high stakes and urgency required by working with a PE portfolio company. They must be able to roll up their sleeves, think and act quickly, prioritize, and be decisive. Operating successfully requires a hands-on consultative approach with a bias toward coaching and action.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDescribing the pace of her job, one CPO said, \u0026ldquo;Everything we do at our firm in the talent and organization space is about speed to impact. It\u0026rsquo;s about fast insight, disciplined process, and data gathering.\u0026rdquo; Any initiative the CPO takes has to prioritize the business and its goals rather than a rigid set of standard practices. CPOs need to possess a real talent for creative, flexible thinking, so that they can contribute without adding burdensome layers to processes and systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eExceptional interpersonal skills\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCPOs need to act as confidantes, which often involves managing many leaders\u0026rsquo; private communication responsibly. Therefore, they must be highly strategic leaders themselves, who build credibility by modeling gravitas. They should be prepared to take unpopular stands while demonstrating low ego, strong communication skills, and flexibility. Most of all, they should always offer solutions. This is especially important for identifying and recommending performance improvements to critical strategic, operational, and organizational areas. It takes an enterprise mindset to determine the right resources, processes, and data to gather and communicate.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eHigh emotional intelligence\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo advise competently, CPOs must be able to read complex human and organizational dynamics. This can be tricky in high stakes situations in which pressure and complexities compound. CPOs need to know when to raise red flags and when to deliver tough messages\u0026mdash;such as saying what the investor or portfolio CEO needs to hear, rather than what they might want to hear.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow to hire a CPO\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt can be a tall order to find some someone with a track record of driving transformation who also has the business acumen to advise C-suite leaders and investment professionals across a multisectoral portfolio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePE firms often find CPOs from three types of backgrounds or combinations thereof: qualified candidates tend to be organizational psychologists who do assessment and coaching work; former HR or executive search professionals; or people with relevant experience in private companies, including in other roles in PE firms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhatever the CPO\u0026rsquo;s original background, it\u0026rsquo;s important to remember that the role changes based on the phase of the deal cycle and that the candidates must be able to perform in all phases. Every CPO will need to be armed with intelligent digital systems to help identify the critical improvements needed for at-risk roles and the organization\u0026rsquo;s health. Lastly, a potential CPO should have firsthand, practical experience in propelling change\u0026mdash;academic or theoretical knowledge isn\u0026rsquo;t enough.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCPOs with backgrounds in organizational psychology\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese candidates often possess deep knowledge of organizational design and effectiveness, including the use of assessments to understand the health of an organization. This background can be helpful when CPOs must look at an underperforming business through the lens of organizational drivers. These candidates are particularly suited to understanding the culture and capabilities that are lacking, analyzing C-suite dynamics, and aligning the company\u0026rsquo;s organizational health to the investment thesis and value creation plan.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCPOs coming from HR or executive search\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA CPO with a strong executive search background and digital rolodex of high-caliber talent can be a huge value-add. Similarly, someone who has been a talent leader and operator inside a company can bring a broad perspective regarding pitfalls to avoid and ways to deliver results.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCPOs with relevant private industry experience\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome candidates come from management consulting or PE firms that have truly invested in this capability. People with these backgrounds can offer a track record of working with CEOs to improve organizational performance, an analytical \u0026ldquo;investor mindset,\u0026rdquo; emotional intelligence, exceptional interpersonal and communication skills, and the ability to operate fast.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHistorically, investment teams haven\u0026rsquo;t systematically thought about talent and organization in a structured way, leading to blind spots\u0026mdash;especially after diligence. PE firms and their limited partners can no longer assume intangible assets such as human capital and culture\u0026mdash;which have been estimated to comprise an average of 52 percent of a company\u0026rsquo;s market value[[footnote 2]]\u0026mdash;will take care of themselves. Bringing in a top-tier CPO gives investment firms and their portfolio companies an edge over firms whose portfolio optimization groups haven\u0026rsquo;t yet evolved to include such a PE firms often reshape top management, boards, as well as the policies and practices inside these companies. Even if the holding period is just three years, changes can endure. Considering that PE firms directly or indirectly employ millions of workers globally, the opportunity to open doors for diverse demographics, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-wins-how-inclusion-matters\"\u003estrengthen companies through diversity\u003c/a\u003e, and positively affect society can be significant.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePE firms ambitious about making lasting changes might consider \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/making-the-world-a-better-place-never-feels-like-work-an-interview-with-chief-dei-officer-indhira-arrington\"\u003ehiring a chief diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) officer\u003c/a\u003e. These executives can add value in three main ways.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe officer can advise on DEI, building a measurable, holistic strategy and helping with cultural matters related to the topic. This includes troubleshooting portfolio company issues and helping recruit a diverse board.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe executive can lead DEI for the PE firm itself. This could include running diagnostics to identify high-priority DEI issues, developing transformation road maps, analyzing industry-specific talent pools to inform action plans, building DEI capabilities across the PE firm, and implementing mentorship or sponsorship programs or employee resource groups.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe officer can increase the pool of underrepresented talent considered for key roles. In most private investment firms with a human capital team, the goal for the DEI partner is not necessarily to source talent (which is typically part of the CPO\u0026rsquo;s executive search function). However, if there is interest in finding a diverse board member, there is a good chance that an investor will tap the DEI partner to assist. In cases where there is explicit interest in hiring a CHRO for a portfolio company, a chief DEI officer may get involved.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to supporting board searches, heads of DEI may also increase the pipeline of underrepresented founders that investors are aware of and with whom they speak and meet. The goal is to ultimately deploy more capital to these entrepreneurs.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Another role to consider: The
